column4: Pre 1950s óstán/ósdán, teach/tigh ósta/ósda in Irish

Pre-1950s bliadhain in Irish. The form bliadhna (bliana today) is used as a special plural form following numerals; the regular plural is blianta). Some eastern Scottish Gaelic dialects use the form bliadhn.[8]
Also réidió and rèidio in spoken Irish and Scottish Gaelic
Pre-1950s genitive ríogh and dative rígh in Irish
In Irish, eaglais is a Roman Catholic house of worship; a Protestant house of worship is called a teampall (temple). As Gaeilge 'séipéal' is also used as it can mean chapel as well.

column5: A number of words are used in both languages for ocean" and "sea"
column7: an fharraige. Caladh or cala (also in the compound "calafort" < "cala-phort") are commonly used in Irish for "harbour"."

column5: Breatain (Britain) is the same in both. The Scottish Gaelic equivalent for Wales is A' Chuimrigh, a Gaelicisation of an Anglicisation of the Welsh Cymru. The Irish for Brittany is An Bhriotáin from Latin Britannia"."
Siubhail means walk" or "stroll" in Scottish Gaelic
column6: but is also a euphemism for death"
